questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to the OPD with symptoms of weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty speaking, hypertension, confusion, and significant weight loss exceeding 7 kgs. He has a history of osteoarthritis and reports consuming 100,000 units of Vitamin D daily for the past 3 months. His laboratory results show a plasma calcium level of 15.5 mg/dL. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D intoxication                                   

 

Option A:

 

  • Therapeutic doses varying from 2000–4000 IU/day or weekly doses are given.
  • Doses above 10,000U/day for long periods may cause toxicity.
  • Symptoms: weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension, and weight loss.
  • Hypercalcemia leads to calcification of soft tissues (calcinosis).
  • Although vitamins are toxic in higher doses, excessive exposure to sunlight does not result in vitamin toxicity, because excess D3 is destroyed by sunlight itself.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Hypercalcemia: Here the blood calcium level is >> 11 mg/dL and there is osteoporosis with X-ray pictures of punched out areas of bone resorption. High calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels and low phosphate levels in blood.

 

Option C: Paget’s disease: It is characterized by osteoclastic bone resorption and disordered replacement of bone, common above 40 years which might affect one or several bones.

 

Option D: Metastatic carcinoma of bone: Drastically high levels of ALP is seen with bone resorption and hypercalcemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin D toxicity leads to hypercalcemia, which can manifest as weakness, polyuria, thirst, confusion, and hypertension due to the increased absorption of calcium from the gut.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 / ed: p 473

questions.text: Which of the following is the active form of Vitamin D?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 25 (OH) 2 Vit-D

 

Option C:

 

  • It is otherwise called as calcitriol
  • 25-HCC is further hydroxylated at the 1st position by 1-alpha hydroxylase In the kidney → forming 1, 25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol (DHCC).
  • As it contains three hydroxyl groups at 1,3 and 25 positions, it is also called as Calcitriol, which is the active form of vitamin and it is a hormone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cholecalciferol: or vitamin D3: is derived either from 7 dehydrocholesterol or ergosterol by the action of ultraviolet radiations. The cis double bond is then isomerized to a trans double bond to give this.

 

Option B. 24, 25(OH)2 vit-D: formed by hydroxylation of 25HCC at the 24th position, a relatively inactive product.

 

Option D. 25-OH vit-D: The cholecalciferol is transported to liver, hydroxylation at 25th position to form 25-hydroxy cholecalciferol.

 

Educational objective:

 

The active form of vitamin D is 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, also known as calcitriol. It is produced in the kidneys from 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25-OH vit-D), which is the major circulating form and is a marker for vitamin D status in the body. Calcitriol acts as a hormone and regulates calcium and phosphate metabolism in the bones, intestines, and kidneys.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469.

questions.text: During a discussion about the metabolism of vitamin D, a physician explains the process of activation to a group of medical residents. The physician asks the residents to identify where 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is hydroxylated by the 1 α-hydroxylase enzyme to form the active form of vitamin D. In which organ does this conversion predominantly occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kidney

 

Option C:

 

  • In the kidney, 25-HCC is hydroxylated at the 1st position by 1-alpha hydroxylase which is located in the mitochondria of PCT.
  • It requires cytochrome P-450, NADPH and ferredoxin.
  • Hence 1, 25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol (DHCC)/ Calcitriol is generated.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Skin: Here, most of the precursor for 1,25(OH)2-D3 synthesis is produced in the Malpighian layer of the epidermis from 7-dehydrocholesterol through UV light-mediated, nonenzymatic photolysis reaction.

 

Option B. Liver: 25-Hydroxylation takes place here.

 

Option D. Heart: No role.

 

Educational objective:

 

25-hydroxycholecalciferol, also known as calcifediol, is hydroxylated by the 1 α-hydroxylase enzyme primarily in the kidneys to form 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), which is the active form of vitamin D. This hydroxylation is crucial for the regulation of calcium homeostasis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e : p 508 , DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 470

choices.text: The condition is diagnosed as osteomalacia, and deficiency of calcium leads to increased   secretion of calbindin.
Chronic kidney disease results in increased production of calcitriol.
Active form of the vitamin D is 25-Hydroxy cholecalciferol.
Vitamin D is required in the diet of individuals with limited exposure to sunlight.

questions.text: An 11-month-old girl is brought in for evaluation due to a bowed appearance of her legs. She is exclusively breastfed without additional supplements. The provided X-ray image shows changes in the long bones consistent with a specific deficiency. Which statement is correct regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D is required in the diet of individuals with limited exposure to sunlight. 

 

Option D:

 

  • The child is diagnosed to have Vitamin D Deficient rickets.
  • Vitamin D should be added in the diet of individuals with limited exposure to sunlight and those with dark skin tone.
  • Breast milk is low in vitamin D and if no supplementation is given it increases the risk of deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The condition is diagnosed as osteomalacia, and deficiency of calcium leads to increased secretion of calbindin:   Osteomalacia is seen in adults and Vitamin D deficiency leads to decreased synthesis of calbindin.

 

Option B. Chronic Kidney Disease: It typically leads to decreased production of calcitriol (the active form of vitamin D) due to impaired renal function, not increased production.

 

Option C. Active form of Vitamin D: The active form of vitamin D is actually 1,25-Dihydrox ycholecalciferol (calcitriol), not 25-Hydroxycholecalciferol, which is a precursor.

 

Educational objective:

 

Rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to improper bone mineralization. Breastfed infants may require vitamin D supplementation, especially with limited sun exposure, which is necessary for endogenous vitamin D production.

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed, pg 550-553

choices.text: Diet of baby food containing leafy vegetables
Diet of baby food containing wheat germ oil

questions.text: A 12-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic with a prominent forehead, limb bowing, broad and tender joints, costochondral swelling, and a deformity of the head described as "craniotabes" resembling a ping-pong ball depression. Considering his age and clinical signs, what is the most appropriate treatment to recommend?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Milk and sunlight exposure

 

Option D:

 

  • This boy is suffering from rickets which is due to deficiency of vitamin D.
  • Liver, fish oil, egg yolk are rich sources of vitamin D.
  • Milk is supplemented by vitamin D.
  • Vitamin D is also formed in skin by exposure to sunlight.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lotion contains retinoic acid: Retinoic acid is a vitamin A derivative which is helpful in treatment of acne but not the case of vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option B. Diet of baby food containing leafy vegetables: Leafy vegetables are a good source of B complex vitamins (specially niacin and cobalamin).

 

Option C. Diet of baby food containing wheat germ oil: Wheat germ oil, sunflower oil, safflower oil, cotton seed oil etc are good sources of vitamin E.

 

Educational objective:

 

Rickets - The recommended treatment is to increase the intake of vitamin D and calcium, which can be achieved with fortified milk and increased exposure to sunlight, as sunlight catalyzes the formation of vitamin D in the skin.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 552-553, Vasudevan 6/e: P 469-473.

choices.text: True, because adipose tissue sequesters vitamin D, reducing its bioavailability.
False, as excessive body weight increases skin synthesis of vitamin D.
True, because excessive body weight enhances the excretion of vitamin D.
False, as vitamin D is water-soluble and not affected by body fat.

questions.text: During a clinical nutrition conference, a presentation highlights the impact of body composition on nutrient status. A case study is discussed involving a 45-year-old patient with obesity undergoing a routine health assessment. The patient's blood work reveals lower than expected levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D]. The presenter poses a question to the audience regarding the association between the patient's body weight and vitamin D status. Which statement is true regarding vitamin D insufficiency in individuals with excessive body weight?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True, because adipose tissue sequesters vitamin D, reducing its bioavailability.

 

Option A:

 

Vitamin D insufficiency is indeed more common in individuals with excessive body weight due to the sequestration of vitamin D in adipose tissue. This reduces the bioavailability of vitamin D for metabolic processes, leading to lower circulating levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D], the primary circulating form of vitamin D.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. False, as excessive body weight increases skin synthesis of vitamin D: This statement is incorrect because skin synthesis of vitamin D is not directly increased by excessive body weight.

 

Option C. True, because excessive body weight enhances the excretion of vitamin D: This statement is misleading. The primary issue is the sequestration of vitamin D in adipose tissue, not enhanced excretion.

 

Option D. False, as vitamin D is water-soluble and not affected by body fat: Vitamin D is actually fat-soluble, which is why it can be sequestered in adipose tissue, affecting its availability in individuals with higher body fat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin D insufficiency is associated with increased risk for metabolic syndrome (MS).
  • Low serum vitamin D3 affects the cellular function in the endocrine pancreas, which is involved in the pathogenesis of obesity and type 2 diabetes.
  • Insufficiency of vitamin 25(OH) D3 is commonly seen in patients with excessive body weight and MS.
  • Thus, vitamin D deficiency is associated with increased risks for hypertension, glucose intolerance, impaired synthesis and secretion of insulin, insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes mellitus, MS, obesity, myocardial infarction, stroke, peripheral vascular disease and asthma.
  • Vitamin D concentration correlates positively with HDL Cholesterol and negatively with serum triglyceride levels and LDL-cholesterol.
  • Vitamin supplementation is beneficial in all these clinical conditions.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 473.

choices.text: Mobilizes calcium to the bone
PTH production is increased
Decreases renal calcium excretion
Increases renal excretion of phosphate

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for severe backache, toothache, and eye twitching. Her laboratory tests indicate a deficiency of vitamin D and hypocalcemia as a result of this deficiency. In response to hypocalcemia, the body activates several compensatory mechanisms. Which of the following is NOT a compensatory effect in response to hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mobilizes calcium to the bone                            

 

Option A:

 

  • PTH plays a major role in conserving only calcium and facilitates excretion of phosphate from kidney tubules.
  • But calcitriol increases reabsorption of calcium and phosphorus from the renal tubules. So both are conserved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. PTH production is increased: This is true. In response to hypocalcemia, the parathyroid glands increase the production of PTH, which helps to raise blood calcium levels by stimulating bone resorption, increasing renal calcium reabsorption, and activating vitamin D.

 

Option C. Decreases renal calcium excretion: This is a correct compensatory response. PTH acts on the kidneys to decrease the excretion of calcium, helping to conserve calcium and raise blood levels.

 

Option D. Increases renal excretion of phosphate: This is also a correct compensatory response. PTH decreases the reabsorption of phosphate in the kidneys, leading to increased excretion, which helps to maintain the calcium-phosphate balance and prevent the precipitation of calcium phosphate in tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In response to hypocalcemia, the body does not mobilize calcium to the bone; instead, it does the opposite. The body releases calcium from the bone to increase serum calcium levels. This is mediated by the parathyroid hormone (PTH), which is released when calcium levels are low.

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed, pg 551-553

choices.text: 1-alpha hydroxylation occurs in kidney
25-alpha hydroxylation occurs in Liver
In absence of sunlight, the daily requirement is 400–600 IU per day
Vitamin D deficiency rickets is associated with Fanconi syndrome

questions.text: In a review session on vitamin D metabolism and its clinical implications, a group of medical students is presented with statements to assess their understanding. They are tasked with identifying the statement that is not accurate regarding vitamin D metabolism and its related conditions. Which of the following statements about vitamin D metabolism is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D deficiency rickets is associated with Fanconi syndrome

 

Option D:

 

  • Vitamin D is a prohormone.
  • The cholecalciferol is transported to liver, where hydroxylation at 25th position by hepatic 25-hydroxylase occurs → forms 25-hydroxy cholecalciferol (25-HCC).
  • This enzyme is a microsomal mono-oxygenase that requires cytochrome P-450 and NADPH.
  • In the kidney, further hydroxylation at the 1st position by 1-alpha hydroxylase takes place gives 1, 25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol (DHCC/Calcitriol).
  • This enzyme requires cytochrome P-450, NADPH and ferredoxin (an iron-sulfur protein).

 

 

Vitamin D resistant rickets is associated with Fanconi syndrome, where the renal tubular reabsorption of bicarbonate, phosphate, glucose and amino acids are deficient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1-alpha hydroxylation occurs in the kidney: This is a correct statement, as the final activation step of vitamin D to its active form, calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), occurs in the kidney.

 

Option B. 25-alpha hydroxylation occurs in the liver: This is also correct. The initial hydroxylation step of vitamin D to 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) occurs in the liver.

 

Option C. In the absence of sunlight, the daily requirement is 400–600 IU per day: This statement is generally correct, as dietary guidelines recommend a daily intake of vitamin D in this range to compensate for the lack of sunlight exposure, which is necessary for the skin to synthesize vitamin D.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency rickets is a condition caused by inadequate vitamin D, leading to impaired bone mineralization. Fanconi syndrome is a disorder of the kidney's proximal tubules, which can lead to various issues, including bone mineralization defects, but it is not directly associated with vitamin D deficiency rickets.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469-473.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with severe headache, vomiting, and a bulging fontanelle. It's revealed that for growth retardation, he was given 60,000 IU of vitamin D capsules twice a week for 5 months by a non-professional. Further examination reveals metastatic calcification in the calf muscles and kidney stones. Lab results show a calcium level of 13.5 mg/dl and a 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol) level of 47 ng/ml. Based on this information, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypervitaminosis D

 

Option A:

 

  • Intake of doses above 10,000 units /day for long periods results in toxicity.
  • Symptoms: weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension and weight loss.
  • Hypercalcemia leads to calcification of soft tissues (metastatic calcification/calcinosis) in vascular and renal tissues.
  • Although vitamin D is toxic in higher doses, excessive exposure to sunlight does not result in vitamin D toxicity, because excess D3 is destroyed by sunlight itself.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rickets: is due to insufficient mineralization of bones seen in children →Bones become soft, pliable and bone growth is markedly affected. Classical bone deformities include weight bearing bones are bent, Bowlegs, knock knee, Rickety rosary and Bossing of frontal bones, pigeon chest and Harrison’s sulcus etc.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis: Occurs after the age of 60 where there is reduced bone strength and an increased risk of fractures due to decreased absorption of vitamin D and reduced levels of androgens/estrogens in old age.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia: is seen in adults, where the bones are softened due to insufficient mineralization, increased osteoporosis and are more prone for fractures. Biochemical parameters: low serum calcium and serum phosphate. Vitamin D deficiency never produces severe hypocalcemia and tetany will not be manifested. Serum alkaline phosphatase is markedly increased.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hypervitaminosis D leads to elevated calcium levels (hypercalcemia), which can cause symptoms like headache, vomiting, and in severe cases, metastatic calcification and renal stones.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 473.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly relates to this discussion?

 

Assertion (A): Vitamin D is a hormone rather than a vitamin.

 

Reasoning (R): It has distinct target organs and its action is similar to steroids.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin D could be considered as a hormone rather than a vitamin because:

 

  • It can be synthesized in the body and released in the circulation.
  • It has distinct target organs.
  • Action of vitamin D is similar to steroid hormones as it binds to a receptor in the cytosol → the receptor-vitamin complex interacts with DNA stimulates the synthesis of calcium binding protein. 

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin D is indeed considered a hormone due to its mechanism of action and the fact that it is synthesized endogenously in the skin upon exposure to sunlight. It acts on different target organs, including the intestines, kidneys, and bones, in a manner similar to steroids, influencing calcium and phosphate homeostasis, which supports the assertion that it functions as a hormone.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469-473.

questions.text: A group of researchers is discussing the potential systemic benefits of vitamin D supplementation beyond its traditional role in bone health. They are considering the broader implications of higher vitamin D intake in various health conditions. According to current evidence, in which of the following conditions might a higher intake of vitamin D be beneficial?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Explanation:

 

There is growing research to suggest that vitamin D plays a role in various metabolic processes and might have benefits beyond bone health. Higher intake of vitamin D has been associated with potential benefits in metabolic syndrome, where it can improve insulin sensitivity and the lipid profile, in prediabetes, where it might help prevent the progression to diabetes, and there is also evidence suggesting a role in cancer prevention or as a supportive treatment due to its effects on cell growth and immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recent studies state that higher intake of vitamin D is protective against prostate and colorectal cancers and metabolic syndrome and prediabetes.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 471-473.

questions.text:
A 1.5-year-old male baby brought by mother to the paediatric OPD with widening of wrist and bone deformity of weight-bearing bones. O/E: child was irritable and lower limb was tender, chest was protruded with prominent costochondral junction. Frontal bulging was noted with delayed closure of cranial sutures.

 

 

 

Laboratory investigations:

 

  • Serum calcium: 7.7 mg/dl (normal 8.5-10.5 mg/dl)
  • Serum Phosphate: 2.8 mg/dl (normal = 3.5-4.5 mg/dl)
  • PTH was also found to be elevated.
  • Level of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol was normal = 25 ng/ml (normal = 30-50 ng/ml)
  • ALP: 665 IU/L (normal = 98-279 IU/L)
  • Level of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol was undetectable.

 

What may be the possible diagnosis in the above case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

Option A:

 

  • Rickets is due to insufficient mineralization of bones seen in children → Bones become soft, pliable and bone growth is markedly affected.
  • Classical bone deformities include weight bearing bones are bent, Bow legs, Knock knee, Rickety rosary and Bossing of frontal bones and pigeon chest.
  • An enlargement of the epiphysis at the lower end of ribs and costochondral junction leads to beading of ribs or rickety rosary.
  • Harrison’s sulcus: transverse depression passing outwards from the costal cartilage to axilla.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteomalacia is seen in adults, where the bones are softened due to insufficient mineralization, increased osteoporosis and are more prone for fractures. Biochemical parameters: low serum calcium and serum phosphate. Vitamin D deficiency never produces severe hypocalcemia and tetany will not be manifested. Serum alkaline phosphatase is markedly increased.

 

Option C. Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake. C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema due to decreased serum albumin levels. Lab findings are not seen.

 

Option D. Tetany: Vitamin D deficiency will not cause tetany.

 

Educational objective:

 

Rickets is characterized by bone softening and deformities due to vitamin D deficiency or disorders in vitamin D metabolism, leading to inadequate mineralization of the bone matrix. The elevated PTH and ALP, along with low calcium and phosphate levels and particularly the undetectable 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (the active form of vitamin D), support this diagnosis. Rickets is more common in pediatric populations, whereas osteomalacia is the adult equivalent.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 472.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with generalized bone pain and difficulty rising from a seated position over the last three months. He reports two fractures in the small bones of his foot within the last two years. On examination, kyphosis is noted. X-ray findings include deficient mineralization of the osteoid matrix and the presence of Looser's zones in the femoral neck. Biochemical tests reveal low serum calcium, phosphorus, and vitamin D levels, along with elevated ALP levels. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteomalacia

 

Option C:

 

  • Osteomalacia is seen in adults, where the bones are softened due to insufficient mineralization, increased osteoporosis and are more prone for fractures.
  • Biochemical parameters: low serum calcium and low serum phosphate.
  • Vitamin D deficiency never produces severe hypocalcemia and tetany will not be manifested.
  • Serum alkaline phosphatase is markedly increased.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rickets is due to insufficient mineralization of bones seen in children à Bones become soft, pliable and bone growth is markedly affected. Classical bone deformities include weight bearing bones are bent, Bowlegs, knock knee, Rickety rosary and Bossing of frontal bones, pigeon chest and Harrison’s sulcus etc.

 

Option B. Osteoporosis: Occurs after the age of 60 where there is reduced bone strength and an increased risk of fractures due to decreased absorption of vitamin D and reduced levels of androgens/estrogens in old age.

 

Option D. Hypervitaminosis D: Intake of doses above 10,000 units /day for long periods. Symptoms: weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension and weight loss. Hypercalcemia leads to calcification of soft tissues (metastatic calcification/calcinosis) in vascular and renal tissues.

 

Educational objective:

 

Osteomalacia is characterized by deficient mineralization of the osteoid matrix in the bones, leading to bone pain, weakness, and susceptibility to fractures. The presence of Looser's zones (pseudofractures), low serum calcium, phosphorus, and vitamin D levels, along with elevated ALP levels, further support the diagnosis of osteomalacia.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 472.

questions.text: Which substance, produced as a result of vitamin D activation, is primarily responsible for its antimicrobial action against Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cathelicidin

 

Option A:

 

Immunomodulatory and antiproliferative effects of vitamin D:

 

  • Prevent infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Within macrophages, synthesis of 1, 25-dihydroxyvitamin D occurs through the activity of CYP27B located in the mitochondria.
  • Pathogen-induced activation of Toll-like receptors in macrophages causes a transcription-induced increase in vitamin D receptor and CYP27B.
  • The resultant production of 1, 25-dihydroxy vitamin D then stimulates the synthesis of cathelicidin, an antimicrobial peptide from the defensin family, that is effective against infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.  IFN-beta is secreted by fibroblasts and has Antiviral effects.

 

Option C. TNF-alpha secreted by Macrophages plays a role in Inflammation, fibrosis, pyrexia, acute phase proteins, necrosis.

 

Option D. IL-6 secreted by activated Th2 cells, hepatocytes and adipocytes plays a role in acute phase response reactions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin D is known to enhance the immune system's ability to fight infections, including tuberculosis, through the induction of antimicrobial peptides. Cathelicidin is one such peptide whose production is increased in response to vitamin D. Cathelicidin has antimicrobial properties that are effective against a broad spectrum of pathogens, including Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 472.
